Reviews.Review content: I read this book in Vietnamese about five or six years back, when I first came to the U.S. I remember bringing this book from Vietnam as a gift from my cousin, whom I refer to as sister. This is a very lovely book from Nguy·ªÖn Nh·∫≠t √Ånh; he captures the easy-going, and exciting life of many Vietnamese children very well, and of course, this book was not written for children, rather, it was for adults who want a ticket back to their childhoods, a trip down the memory lane. This book serves that pur

I had a good five minute long internal debate with myself before reviewing this book because I read the translated work (the book is originally in Vietnamese) and I have mixed feelings about the book.

Just the sweetest. This is a fast and enjoyable read and truly blurs the line between fiction and biography. This should be required reading for grown ups; it is impossible to read this without recollecting the forgotten magic of childhood and the anguish of having to grow up and away from innocence.
i'm out of words to describe
The frequent contrasting between childhood and adulthood made by the author is reminiscent of the famous French work "The Little Prince" and the Japanese novel "Totto-chan".

This book was a phenomenon when it was first published in Vietnam, partly because of the author's fame, partly because the book itself is truly wonderful: a queer sense of humor, extraordinary thoughts that suit all type of readers: kids, teenagers and adults. I never liked Nguy·ªÖn Nh·∫≠t √Ånh and actually distaste his previous books entirely, but to my surprise I found this book hard to put down once started!
Nguyen Nhat Anh has said about this book that he did not write this book for children, but instead he wrote it to those

Rich with one liners and moments where you'll laugh aloud. Just one to share here: "Adults like to keep the cobwebs out of their attics - to clean up the past. But when you brush those cobwebs away, you may be brushing off diamond dust." Translated into English from Vietnamese. You'll be a more informed and developed reader of literature by experiencing this short fiction piece.
Lovely little book. Makes you remember good things from your own childhood and lighten up.
hilarious, remind me of fun memories in my childhood, must read book for adults. how much the book valued?- well, the older you get, the more it makes you cry- it is that kind of books
But you can, without a ticket, revisit your childhood any time. Just step out of the shallow man=made canal and into deep water. p155

A very enjoyable slice of childhood. A short read, the author recounts various episodes of his time growing up in Vietnam. This is in the same style as another very good book called "Totto-chan: The girl in the Window" (life in Japan as a child). It is a pleasant recollection of a childhood adventures that reminded me of Mark Twain's writing.

I almost returned this to the library unread since I'm trying to read my own books, but I'm glad I didn't. It's a short little book, only about 140 pages, but it did a great job at capturing childhood, or more clearly, an adult's memory of childhood. I liked seeing how someone growing up across the world from me could have similar childhood memories. It reads like a memoir and felt very real, even though it's a novel (or is it?). It made me think about all of my memories of playing with the kids
This book is somehow overrated.

There's is eloquence in simplicity, it is sometimes said, and I found that to be the case with this novel. It is a short but impactful recall to the creativity and enthusiastic wonder that defines childhood and contrasts the abundant monotony of adulthood.
I have read this 3 time:

This is an author really really loved by the Vietnamese, and I guess, you have to have grown up in Vietnam to appreciate him because I find this book - and other media by this guy to be frankly terrrible and they all have this horrible misogynistic undertone and... yeah.

On my trip to Ho Chi Minh last year, I wanted so badly to bring back Vietnamese authors‚Äô translated works. I finally read it yesterday (thanks to COVID-19 lockdown) and take my sweet time reading it. It is a children‚Äôs book made for adults, hence the title. I smiled all the way through reading it and smiled upon finishing it. What a great book. A simple but thought provoking one. It will be a book I will reread again and again and again.

Is this really a novel, or a memoir masquerading as a novel? I'm not sure...but I did enjoy the experience. In its exploration of childhood, reflected in the eyes of adults, it's sweet, outrageous, funny, and poignant. It treats the fourth wall between writer and reader like a permeable membrane, and the end result is something slightly kooky and off-centre, but joyously entertaining.

I read this when i was secondary school when i was not not old enough to feel related and grasp all those bittersweet moments NNA want readers to understand. However, I can somehow feel the bittersweet of the ending and some of the emotions from the writer throughout the novel. Maybe one day, when i get older, I'll read this book once again and be able to truly understand it.

This book is about some stories that everybody has experienced once in their lives when they were young. These stories are really close to each person's life. But I don't like it very much because it has some romantic details which I hate :">

As its name, just give you a ticket to come back to childhood years. There were packs of candy given each other, afternoons run away from home to steal mangos, fly kites on rice paddies and catch field crabs ...
I am given this book during this time as a therapy for the soul.
A pitch-perfect return to the mind of childhood.
A great read for a family oriented person, big or small.
"Many people are afraid of sadness, but I'm not one of them. I'm only afraid of boredom. Sadness, in that respect, is an excellent remedy, since it expands to fill almost any void."
I‚Äôm not into his writing but the stories are lovely and relatable
Underneath the collection of his silly childhood memories is the call that sometimes, behaving like a child is not a bad idea for many adults
The story of childhood makes me feel like I grew up
the book is bold, pure, easy-understanding and nostalgic which reminded me of all the good old days, of my childhood.

Bong Bong Len Troi (rising balloons) by Nguyen Nhat Anh describes a family of kindness and decency, of sacrifice and share that every member has for each other. The book also shows the restless fight against poverty, prejudice and discrimination and the dream for a brighter future of Thuong and Tai Khon.

What was the book about? Maybe the book is only published in Vietnamese but perhaps you could enlighten your non-Vietnamese-proficient Goodreads friends by at least touching on the content in your reviews.

Junta wrote: "What was the book about? Maybe the book is only published in Vietnamese but perhaps you could enlighten your non-Vietnamese-proficient Goodreads friends by at least touching on the content in your ..."

Haha...right, will take notice next time. The book is about trending subjects on Vietnamese newspapers in the early 2000s. For example: ebooks, Bruce Lee films, Western calligraphy, Chinese towns, Yahoo 360!, etc. I like how the author addresses these social matters, although I felt like I'd have enjoyed this more if I have lived in Hanoi, at least for some time. The Vietnam that is described in this book is still a foreign country to youngsters like me, in general. This is why I'm trying to know more about it, as you may have noticed.
(Sorry if what I was trying to say doesn't make any sense. It's the reason why I desperately need bullet points).
No need to apologise, your review and comment paint a good picture of the book and your reading experience :-)

Bong Bong Len Troi (rising balloons) by Nguyen Nhat Anh describes a family of kindness and decency, of sacrifice and share that every member has for each other. The book also shows the restless fight against poverty, prejudice and discrimination and the dream for a brighter future of Thuong and Tai Khon.
The plot is interesting with many twists. Love the way the story was told, naturally and simply. There was empathy in the characters' hearts.

A great read for a family oriented person, big or small.
A pitch-perfect return to the mind of childhood.
I am given this book during this time as a therapy for the soul.

As its name, just give you a ticket to come back to childhood years. There were packs of candy given each other, afternoons run away from home to steal mangos, fly kites on rice paddies and catch field crabs ...

This book is about some stories that everybody has experienced once in their lives when they were young. These stories are really close to each person's life. But I don't like it very much because it has some romantic details which I hate :">

I read this when i was secondary school when i was not not old enough to feel related and grasp all those bittersweet moments NNA want readers to understand. However, I can somehow feel the bittersweet of the ending and some of the emotions from the writer throughout the novel. Maybe one day, when i get older, I'll read this book once again and be able to truly understand it.

Is this really a novel, or a memoir masquerading as a novel? I'm not sure...but I did enjoy the experience. In its exploration of childhood, reflected in the eyes of adults, it's sweet, outrageous, funny, and poignant. It treats the fourth wall between writer and reader like a permeable membrane, and the end result is something slightly kooky and off-centre, but joyously entertaining.

On my trip to Ho Chi Minh last year, I wanted so badly to bring back Vietnamese authors‚Äô translated works. I finally read it yesterday (thanks to COVID-19 lockdown) and take my sweet time reading it. It is a children‚Äôs book made for adults, hence the title. I smiled all the way through reading it and smiled upon finishing it. What a great book. A simple but thought provoking one. It will be a book I will reread again and again and again.

This is an author really really loved by the Vietnamese, and I guess, you have to have grown up in Vietnam to appreciate him because I find this book - and other media by this guy to be frankly terrrible and they all have this horrible misogynistic undertone and... yeah.
I have read this 3 time:

There's is eloquence in simplicity, it is sometimes said, and I found that to be the case with this novel. It is a short but impactful recall to the creativity and enthusiastic wonder that defines childhood and contrasts the abundant monotony of adulthood.

I almost returned this to the library unread since I'm trying to read my own books, but I'm glad I didn't. It's a short little book, only about 140 pages, but it did a great job at capturing childhood, or more clearly, an adult's memory of childhood. I liked seeing how someone growing up across the world from me could have similar childhood memories. It reads like a memoir and felt very real, even though it's a novel (or is it?). It made me think about all of my memories of playing with the kids
This book is somehow overrated.

A very enjoyable slice of childhood. A short read, the author recounts various episodes of his time growing up in Vietnam. This is in the same style as another very good book called "Totto-chan: The girl in the Window" (life in Japan as a child). It is a pleasant recollection of a childhood adventures that reminded me of Mark Twain's writing.
But you can, without a ticket, revisit your childhood any time. Just step out of the shallow man=made canal and into deep water. p155
hilarious, remind me of fun memories in my childhood, must read book for adults. how much the book valued?- well, the older you get, the more it makes you cry- it is that kind of books

Rich with one liners and moments where you'll laugh aloud. Just one to share here: "Adults like to keep the cobwebs out of their attics - to clean up the past. But when you brush those cobwebs away, you may be brushing off diamond dust." Translated into English from Vietnamese. You'll be a more informed and developed reader of literature by experiencing this short fiction piece.
Nguyen Nhat Anh has said about this book that he did not write this book for children, but instead he wrote it to those
Lovely little book. Makes you remember good things from your own childhood and lighten up.

This book was a phenomenon when it was first published in Vietnam, partly because of the author's fame, partly because the book itself is truly wonderful: a queer sense of humor, extraordinary thoughts that suit all type of readers: kids, teenagers and adults. I never liked Nguy·ªÖn Nh·∫≠t √Ånh and actually distaste his previous books entirely, but to my surprise I found this book hard to put down once started!
The frequent contrasting between childhood and adulthood made by the author is reminiscent of the famous French work "The Little Prince" and the Japanese novel "Totto-chan".

Just the sweetest. This is a fast and enjoyable read and truly blurs the line between fiction and biography. This should be required reading for grown ups; it is impossible to read this without recollecting the forgotten magic of childhood and the anguish of having to grow up and away from innocence.
i'm out of words to describe

Review content: I had a good five minute long internal debate with myself before reviewing this book because I read the translated work (the book is originally in Vietnamese) and I have mixed feelings about the book.
List Comment: You are totally right. This guy tends to wander in his own thoughts and as time went by, his writings got more and more incoherent. He kept using sentences like "Back then, the girl used to do this and that", "A while ago, I did not use to do this and that", "Back then, my mother/grandmother used to do this and that". I remember there was one time I was reading his book, and within 3 paragraphs, he jumped from present day to the past and to the present day again, then to the past, and then to the present day again good LORD. And within that 3 paragraphs, he had like used his "Back then..." 3-4 times. After that I kind of gave up on him. His writing is no doubt the 'friendliest' Vietnamese lit out there, and can be read by anybody, but my advice would be that you should read his books that were written before 2000.

Becky wrote: "You are totally right. This guy tends to wander in his own thoughts and as time went by, his writings got more and more incoherent. He kept using sentences like "Back then, the girl used to do this..."
I get what you mean! I actually had to read this one part thrice because he said he ended up doing this... and in the next part he said oh but I didn't.
Turns out, he did it in his childhood while playacting with friends, but in real life he didn't actually do it.
Seriously...
I think it's because the translation.I gave this book 3 stars but the translated?2stars

Yes, Ng·∫°n sounds like a loser, H√† Lan must be a utilitarian girl, D≈©ng is an f-boy. But that's why this story could have touched so many people- because it's realistic and it's relatable. Just read it to be ready for the upcoming movie :)). Couldn‚Äôt undertand why people like it so much. Ha Lan is questionable, Ngan is quite romantically dumb, and poor Tra Long, her whole existence is just a replacement. The eye is not well described so i couldn‚Äôt imagine how beautiful it was. The writing style is simple and easy to read but could not trigger much feelings nor imagination.
OK THIS IS THE WORST BOOK I'VE EVER READ WOMEN'S RIGHTS

I am not a fan of NNA. Personally, his storyline usually doesn't touch my feeling, it 's boring and safe. But I highly appreciate his writing style, he exclusively creates a combination of bitness and sweetness, all-ages story. Maybe, I am a picky person who tries hard to find something more profound. The senses appearing through his language description such as Vietnam village, humans, and traditional culture are very beautiful and real as much as make us feel like we daily meet it somewhere. "

I almost threw my Kindle across the room (lol) for the characters in the story angered me. But that also meant it was a great book, as it was capable of evoking emotions from readers. I think it was tragic. It was tragic because Nguyen Nhat Anh didn't give readers a happy ending, but it was more tragic because of the choices the characters made - choices that defy logic (hence the tableflip).
Love is blind. I like it how NNA made his point so clear... until Tra Long. The later chapters and the ending are pretty rushed.

The first story of Nguyen Nhat Anh that I have ever read, it affects to my feeling a lot. This is attravctive by the characters‚Äô inner feeling expression words, once read, can not quit. Full emotion however unhappy ending, with others, it is a happy one but to me, it was not, unfair for Ng·∫°n.

I hate this god forsaken novel with a passion. The main character is passive. So passive that it makes the who story unreadable. Ngan doesn't have much substance besides he "love Ha Lan" and he knows how to play the guitar (a bit). I'm sorry but that doesn't make a main charater interesting or compelling. The main character's obssession with Ha Lan is also horribly written. He barely knows the girl. Is this obssession even healthy or justified? Not once on the book was the reader shown what make
saddest book I've ever read, but also one of the best books.
saddest book I ever read

Honestly, I had not had a strong inclination for cheesy romantic, so it was not appealing to me at first. However, I decided to give it a chance as this book was one of the most successful books of Nguyen Nhat Anh.
Summary:
A mixture of fiction and literature?!

I have known about Nguyen Nhat Anh for a long time, but not much about his works. Only when I read mat biec did I realize the beauty of Nguyen Nhat Anh‚Äôs works. I could not stop reading because the inexplainable feelings carried by the story kept running inside my heart. I read the book from the beginning until the end. And somewhere in mat biec, I see my self, I lived my childhood once again because I used to love, love passionately like Ngan.

one of the most painful love stories i had ever read T___T why Ngan sacrificed his life for his first love but still didn't have happiness? :((( i didn't know how many times i cry for him, a real man.

A first half of book is so interesting, but when I close this book, I feel fuckin sad. I can't stand the end of this love story. Although they had a pure chilhood, adulthood many things changed. Lots of sentences have rhythym like a poem, the author was good at understanding thinking and feeling of charaters

A Vietnamese novel and execlusively made for Vietnamese who has or used to have an unresponding love. Personally, i think this is a book who can read by all ages. The story was sad but beautiful, and the author, a master in this type, he created a story of all-age and i think from my subjective view this is one of his best book he has ever written.
another love story from my fav author!

Ngan's priceless love to Ha Lan has been a beautiful symbol of the truly love. Depends on each one's thoughts about the masterpiece, they themselves may discover some interesting emotional experiences in childhood's love of a dreamer like Ngan... The empathy may occur if you had a very nice experience similar before.
Non-Spoiler
This is the second time I read this book. It's a romantic story with sad ending.

One of the best book I have ever read from Nguy·ªÖn Nh·∫≠t √Ånh. The book tells the story of a love lasting through many years from the main character to his girl friend. The love lasts even more than one generation, lasts through many changes in people lives.

Wonderful books !!! This book is so touching and appealing that I read a whole book in one day. ( my new record). The story is delicately presented and has a surprising yet reasonable ending. It also reminds me of my grandma strongly. Recommend for someone to read it this summer.

I think the final decision of Ngan is right, It make sense that Ngan is probably is grow up through 30 years of the lovesick with Ha Lan. And I guest that he could find out the answer for what his wonder, "Is love Forgiveness or Selfish?"

Sometimes in life there are things we want but cannot have. Therefore, we must try to overcome difficulties and seek new opportunities. The past has passed the present and the future is what we need to look at. A sad but very good love story.

First time reading Nguyen Nhat Anh book with a desperate plot, the only answer for unrequited love is that they are not meant for one another. Yet his soaring wording elicits warm feelings and inspires awe afterall‚ù§Ô∏è
An emotional story about Vietnamese country, love and memories
Too sad!!
The best book I'd ever read of NNA's book.
This book is my most favourite among NNA's books! Love everything about it!

I have known about Nguyen Nhat Anh for a long time, but not much about his works. Only when I read mat biec did I realize the beauty of Nguyen Nhat Anh‚Äôs works. I could not stop reading because the inexplainable feelings carried by the story kept running inside my heart. I read the book from the beginning until the end. And somewhere in mat biec, I see my self, I lived my childhood once again because I used to love, love passionately like Ngan.
Nguyen Nhat Anh is incredible at revoking feelings that we can all relate to at some points in our life through stories that are so ordinary and simple. Perhaps that's where the magic is.

The first story of Nguyen Nhat Anh that I have ever read, it affects to my feeling a lot. This is attravctive by the characters‚Äô inner feeling expression words, once read, can not quit. Full emotion however unhappy ending, with others, it is a happy one but to me, it was not, unfair for Ng·∫°n.
saddest book I've ever read, but also one of the best books.

I almost threw my Kindle across the room (lol) for the characters in the story angered me. But that also meant it was a great book, as it was capable of evoking emotions from readers. I think it was tragic. It was tragic because Nguyen Nhat Anh didn't give readers a happy ending, but it was more tragic because of the choices the characters made - choices that defy logic (hence the tableflip).

I am not a fan of NNA. Personally, his storyline usually doesn't touch my feeling, it 's boring and safe. But I highly appreciate his writing style, he exclusively creates a combination of bitness and sweetness, all-ages story. Maybe, I am a picky person who tries hard to find something more profound. The senses appearing through his language description such as Vietnam village, humans, and traditional culture are very beautiful and real as much as make us feel like we daily meet it somewhere. "
Love is blind. I like it how NNA made his point so clear... until Tra Long. The later chapters and the ending are pretty rushed.
OK THIS IS THE WORST BOOK I'VE EVER READ WOMEN'S RIGHTS

Review content: Just read it to be ready for the upcoming movie :)). Couldn‚Äôt undertand why people like it so much. Ha Lan is questionable, Ngan is quite romantically dumb, and poor Tra Long, her whole existence is just a replacement. The eye is not well described so i couldn‚Äôt imagine how beautiful it was. The writing style is simple and easy to read but could not trigger much feelings nor imagination.
List Comment: People love it because it's realistic. A good novel doesn't always have to have perfect characters. If you want perfect and likeable characters that much, you should read "The Notebook". Yes, Ng·∫°n sounds like a loser, H√† Lan must be a utilitarian girl, D≈©ng is an f-boy. But that's why this story could have touched so many people- because it's realistic and it's relatable. We don't need to be gods to love, to hate, to have meaningful memories and bitter experiences. Ng·∫°n, as I said- is just a below-average guy, but his loyal with Ha Lan is a symbol for a type of love that so many people on earth have experienced: the innocent, no self-interest emotions toward your crush, your first love. Sometimes this type of love is harmful to both of the parties, but it's love regardless and that's why Ng·∫°n's emotions toward H√† Lan in this novel should be seen with empathy even they are not sensible at all. H√† Lan can be observed as a typical beautiful girl who changes her environment from rural to urban. Her life can turn in two directions - either to become independent and to be happy, or it can also be very painful. Nguy·ªÖn Nh·∫≠t √Ånh made her make a choice and we should not criticise it, but to learn from her decision's consequences. Furthermore- About D≈©ng, I don't think he's that bad. Yeah, he's pretty bad, but in this novel, he represents the guys who are young and have nothing to worry about life and/or financial problems. Guys like that can be carefree, heartless or to be seen by some people as cruel but it's a fact of life and there is little thing we can do about it other than protecting and improving ourselves. And lastly, Tr√† Long- a cute girl with all the good traits, but turns out to be just a copy or someone else's replacement. It's bitter and it's hard to accept, but again it's realistic. Trust me, if you dive deep enough into love, someday you may find yourself- or your partner just to be a replacement for a ghost of the past. But I hope that you all won't have to live a whole life in that role, and that's what Nguy·ªÖn Nh·∫≠t √Ånh are trying to say with us, by using Ng·∫°n and Tr√† Long.

So, did you see? "M·∫Øt bi·∫øc" is not a perfect love story, not even a good story. But it's a great novel about the love and the life of young Vietnamese people in the 60s (or 70s). The emotions in the novel are real, and I think that not only you and me, or people nowaday but also people in the future can feel related to it. Because it's love, and love is eternal.
